package nov27;

import java.util.HashSet;
import java.util.LinkedHashSet;
import java.util.TreeSet;

public class SetJava {

	public static void main(String[] args) {
		// TODO Auto-generated method stub
		
		// Set 3 types --> 1) HashSet 
		// 				   2) LinkedHashSet
		//				   3) TreeSet
		
		// 1) HashSet --> Stores only unique values , does not follow order 
		
		HashSet<Integer> set1=new HashSet<Integer>();   
		set1.add(1);  
		set1.add(2);
		set1.add(3);  
		set1.add(4);
		set1.add(3); // duplicate
		set1.add(4); // duplicate
		
		System.out.println(set1);
		
		// 2) LinkedHashSet --> Stores only unique values , Removes Duplicates !!! Follows insertion order
		
		LinkedHashSet<String> set2 =new LinkedHashSet<String>();  
		set2.add("Tamizh");  
		set2.add("Amrith");  
		set2.add("Sanjay");  
		set2.add("Harjith");  
		set2.add("Sanjay");  // duplicate
		set2.add("Harjith"); // duplicate 
		
		System.out.println(set2);
		
		// 3) TreeSet --> Stores only unique values , but it follows "" Ascending order "" , so it is FASTER !!!
		
		TreeSet<String> set3 = new TreeSet<String>();
		set3.add("c");
		set3.add("f");
		set3.add("a");
		set3.add("b");
		set3.add("e");
		set3.add("d");
		
		System.out.println(set3); // prints in ascending order
		

	}

}
